div.head: A Jurie of Seamsters, and their verdit vpon Band, Ruffe, and Cuffe.

div.l: I View'd my wares, and found Bands case was good,
And Ruffe and Cuffe, if rightly vnderstood.
The fault the Printers was; for he mistooke,
And made a writ of Error in the booke.
LEt Iudgement trie to whom the faults belong,
'T wil say, the Printer did Ruffe, Cuffe, Band wrong.
I See no fault for which I iudge it meet,
That Ruffe, Cuffe, Band should here stand in a sheet.
THe work's well viewd, each man in it doth pry,
It cannot scape the very Needles eye:
Yet this be sure, if ought had beene o'reslipt,
The fault by me should not haue scap't vnript.
NOt for to cleare you, Ruffe, Cuffe, Band, come I
Hither to th' Tearme: but rather here to buy
A prohibition for to make no more,
Lest by this art, we Seampsters grow but poore.
MY verdit's this, The accuser is in fault:
To picke a hole in Ruffe, Cuffe, Band, 'tis naught.
THey presse Ruffe, Cuffe, & Band: (what reason's in't)
And yet desire, they still should stand in print.
THinke not your face so good, as need no band:
Dare not to spoile great Ruffe; set not your hand,
Cuffe to disgrace. All Linnen els will take
Vp armes for Ruffe, and Cuffe, and Band, and make
Their enemies like Friers, wool-ward to lie,
Or weare a Dishclout, yet afore they die.
THe faults in Ruffe, Cuffe, Band, are whose, doe you thinke?
The Printers? I. He spoild them with his Inke.
WHat though the Printer Ruffe, Cuffe, Band hath stayn'd?
Ile get it forth, or else let me be blam'd.
For all his blacke foule fingers neuer feare,
But that the Landresse she can make them cleare.
IF this Ruffe, Cuffe, and Band condemned are,
Weele looke vnto the Linnen, that we weare.
Did you desire good Ware, you'd rather plead,
The owner sure hath spunne a goodly thread.
WHē Cuffe at the Barre is forst to hold his hand,
And there condemned is with Ruffe & Band,
You that can see in them there's such defects,
High time it is to looke vnto your necks.
